  9. Checkpoint 2

Checkpoint 2

  1. Complete the sortNoSuit() method in PokerHand.java (on the previous page). You can look at the similar sortWithSuit() method for help; just ignore the suit comparison.

    Try out your code for this method, and the next two, using DeckTest2.java.

  2. Complete the isStraight() method. A straight is whenever you have 5 cards in a row, for example: 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. (Note: We are interpreting the ranks literally, meaning that we ignore the situation in many versions of the game of poker in which the ace or 1 card may be counted as higher than a king.)
  3. Complete the isFullHouse() method. A full house is whenever you have a pair and a triple, such as 3, 3, K, K, K or 3, 3, 3, K, K.
  4. Add the code for DeckTest3.java to your project and run it. This will use your Deck class to generate a million 5-card hands, and then use your PokerHand class to count how many are flushes, how many are straights, and how many are full houses.
    • If your Deck's select method is implemented correctly, you should see a proportion of about .00198 for the flushes (5148 possible flushes out of 2598960 possible 5-card combinations).
    • If your methods from the first three steps are implemented correctly, you should also see about .00355 for straights and about .00144 for full houses.
